citeinfo.title: EnviroAtlas - Thermoelectric Water Use by 12-Digit HUC for the Conterminous United States

pubinfo.publish: U.S. EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Exposure Research Laboratory (NERL)

idinfo.useconst: None. Please check sources, scale, accuracy, currency and other available information. Please confirm that you are using the most recent copy of both data and metadata. Acknowledgement of the EPA would be appreciated.

descript.abstract: This EnviroAtlas dataset is a summary of the thermoelectric water consumption based on the December 2016 US Energy Information Administration (EIA) monthly electric generator inventory, a 2014 review of water consumption for electricity generation (Macknick et al.), and reported water consumption estimates from a 2009 Department of Energy (DOE) report. The file contains total water withdrawal and consumption in gallons per year by 12-digit hydrologic unit codes (HUC_12s) from the boundary file named NHDPlusV2_WBDSnapshot_EnviroAtlas_CONUS. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).
descript.purpose: The summarized data provides an indication of estimated yearly fresh water demand by industry for production of electrical power. The overall goal of EnviroAtlas is to employ and develop the best available science to map indicators of ecosystem services production, demand, and drivers for the nation.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

dataqual.logic: Tests for integrity have not been performed.
dataqual.complete: Features represented have not been tested for completeness

horizpa.horizpar: Data were collected using methods that have unknown accuracy (EPA National Geospatial Data Policy [NGDP] Accuracy Tier 10). For more information, please see EPA's NGDP at https://www.epa.gov/geospatial/geospatial-policies-and-standards

procstep.procdesc: Acquired December 2016 US Energy Information Administration (EIA) monthly electric generator inventory
Selected those plants in operation and that used water in electrical generation process
Created point layer using latitude and longitude from data file in ArcGIS using Add XY data.

Used average gallon per MWh (megawatt hour) per fuel type to calculate total water withdrawal and consumption amounts for each plant. The fuel types include Coal, Nuclear, Natural Gas, Oil, Solar Energy, Biomass, and Geothermal. The estimates for all but oil came from the Macknick et al 2012 paper. Oil estimates came from the NETL 2009 report.
Used spatial join to link points file to HUC_12 boundaries
Summarized water withdrawal and consumption by HUC_12 in ArcMap

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

metainfo.metstdn: FGDC Content Standard for Digital Geospatial Metadata

cntorgp.cntorg: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Research and Development-Sustainable and Healthy Communities Research Program, EnviroAtlas

attr.attrdef: Twelve Digit Hydrologic Unit Code. This field provides a unique 12-digit code for each subwatershed. Numbers were assigned in an upstream to downstream fashion. Where no downstream/upstream relationship could be determined, numbers were assigned in a clockwise fashion.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary Dataset; Chapter 3 of Section A; Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3.

attr.attrdef: Number of thermoelectric plants per HUC_12

Total Water Withdrawal in HUC_12 in gallons per year. Withdrawal measures the amount of water that is withdrawn from the stream, regardless of whether it is consumed. Some of the withdrawn water is returned to the stream.
Total Water Consumption in HUC_12 in gallons per year. Water consumption measures water that is withdrawn and consumed without being returned to the stream.

Total Water Withdrawal in HUC_12 in millions of gallons per day. Withdrawal measures the amount of water that is withdrawn from the stream, regardless of whether it is consumed. Some of the withdrawn water is returned to the stream.
Total Water Consumption in HUC_12 in millions of gallons per day. Water consumption measures water that is withdrawn and consumed without being returned to the stream.

overview.eaover:
In 2017 the source for the thermoelectric plant data changed from EPA eGRID (Emissions & Generation Resource Integrated Database) to US energy Information Administration (EIA) monthly electric generator inventory for December. (U.S. Energy Information Administration, Form EIA-860, 'Annual Electric Generator Report' and Form EIA-860M, 'Monthly Update to the Annual Electric Generator Report.').
The EIA December 2016 data file provided currently in operation plants locations, the type of energy source, and a capacity factor for energy generation in megawatts (MW). Capacity from facilities with a total generator nameplate capacity less than 1 MW are excluded from this report. This exclusion may represent a significant portion of capacity for some technologies such as solar photovoltaic generation.
The average gallon per MWh per fuel type was used to calculate total water withdrawal and consumption amounts for each plant. The fuel types include Coal, Nuclear, Natural Gas, Oil, Solar Energy, Biomass, and Geothermal. The estimates for all but oil came from the Macknick et al. 2012 paper (Macknick, J., Newmark, R., Heath, G, and Hallett, K.C. 2012. Operational water consumption and withdrawal factors for electricity generating technologies: a review of existing literature. Environ. Res. Lett 7:1-10). Oil estimates came from the 2009 National Energy Technology Laboratory (www.netl.doe.gov) report titled "Estimating Freshwater Needs to Meet Future Thermoelectric Generation Requirements."
A comprehensive list of metric creation steps is included in the Processing Steps.
